The strong faction in Kerman opposed to Sirdar Muhtaaham, continued to do its best to undermine the Governor General’s es position at Tehran by a seri^f^ of ill-founded complaints. His Majesty’s Minister on more than one occasion telegraphed to Sirdar Muhtasham in a reassuring strain, promising him his support in spite of the fact that he had been prejudiced in the eyes of the Prime Minister by the continuous complaints * brought“brought against him. It has been suggested that Lecoffre, the Financial Agent in Kerman, who is strongly biassed against all B&khtiaris, may be at the bottom of these intrigues. In the uiddie oT October, the change in Southern Go Tremor ships, which has been pending for some time, was finally decided on. Sirdar Huhtasham is to proceed to « Ispahan and his place at Kerman will be taken by Sirdar 2affar, who owes his appointment to special instructions issued by His Majesty’s Government thet the Bakhti&ri Khans are not to be alienated. His Majesty’s Minister considers that the new incumbent will require to be kept well in hand, i although he has given satisfactory assurances. Knox, C.I.E., Officiating Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, To—The Hon’ble Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Percy Cox, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Foreign Secretary to the Government of India, Foreign and Political Department, Simla. I have the honour to forward, for the information of the Government of India a resume of recent telegraphic correspondence on the subject of local politics at Kirman. In the beginning of September the Governor-General, Sirdar Muhtasham broached the subject of his taking a hundred gendarmes and a maxim gun to carry out a disciplinary tour in his district. His Majesty^ Consul, while approv ing in principle of the tour, viewed with misgivings the proposal to employ gendarmes as likely to delay the carrying out of the work for which they came to Kirman, namely the protection of the Bandar Abbas-Kirman, trade route. His Majesty’s Minister was not opposed to the employment of gendarmes, provided the tour proposed was likely to react favourably on the condition of the road, but thought that apart from this, it was undesirable that the Governor-General should proceed on tour until the question of the redistribution of the Southern Governorships was decided. It appears that His Majesty’s Minister has Sirdar Muhtasham in mind as Governor-General at Ispahan, but fears that open support would in all probability call forth Russian opposition as in the case of Samsam-es-Sultaneh and Sirdar Bahadur, and that the only way to support his candidature is to get the Rus sians to put him forward as their own nominee. It is interesting to note that the Swedes at Kirman do not intend placing their men on the road until they are guaranteed payment of the expenses of the maintenance of the force for a considerable period. They point out, and it must be acknowledged with some force, that if their men were not paid it would be difficult to prevent them looting and robbing, if scattered over some 300 miles of country. Governor-General has submitted to me through Honorary Vice-Consul that ' he only consented to come here on a definite promise that he would be enabled to make an expedition against Baluchis. The Nasir-ul*Mamalik Rais of the Bakhtiari sowars who have come here to escort Misbah-i-Divan called on Captain Biscoe a few days ago, and seemed extremely unwilling to proceed to Chahbar, even if funds were provided. He said that the idea of sending the Misbah-i'Divan to establish order in Baluchistan with 40 men was absurd (which it undoubtedly is); that it was beginning to get hot, and the Bakhtiaris were unaccustomed to a hot climate, and that it would be impossible to attempt to move from Chahbar before the autumn, and therefore he saw no use in going there. All this is perfectly true, and it is ridiculous to suppose that the Baluchis who have openly resisted the Persian Government for the last 7 years are now going to submit at the magic of the name of a man who started life as a small shop-keeper in Ahwaz. I HAVE the honour to transmit to you herewith copy of a Confidential despatch which I have received from His Majesty’s Consul at Kerman, upon the subject of the increasing prevalence of Baluchi raids that not only threaten towns in which there are considerable British carpet weaving interests, but even the city of Kerman itself. Captain Lorimer points out with much reason that the situation is fast becoming an intolerable one when Baluchi raiders not only threaten the Kerman-Bunder Abbas trade route in large numbers, but even might menace the town of Kerman itself in the absence of the Governor-General, should that official at a critical moment be absent with the bulk of his forces in some other part of the province. The remedy for this unsatisfactory state of things lies, Captain Lorimer appears to think, in offensive operations into Persian Baluchistan, but he rightly considers that no good purpose would be served by such an expedition unless the necessary steps were taken to secure the establishment of a permanent administration in Persian Baluchistan under a capable Governor, who should be independent of the Governor-General of Kerman, and be provided with such a military force as would enable him to maintain order and put a stop to raiding. Such an arrangement is highly desirable, but Captain Lorimer proceeds to point out in his despatch all the difficulties that attend the execution of such a plan under existing conditions. An expedition under a Bakhtiari Governor-General would, he shows, be of a purely ephemeral nature, with, as its main object, the amassing of as much plunder as possible by the leader. And yet with a Bakhtiari Governor-General there is at least some chance that some punitive measures can be undertaken, because the Bakhtiari khans are always accompanied by a certain military force of their own tribesmen. Nothing but a purely defensive attitude could be assumed by any other Governor-General that the Persian Government would be likely to send to Kerman, because he would have no force, beyond the somewhat unreliable levies he could raise locally, to oppose to the Baluchi raiders. The present Governor-General, Serdar Mohtashem Bakhtiari, who has not left Tehran, has had the Baluch question seriously under consideration in concert with the Minister of the Interior, and contemplates undertaking a military expedition, on which he hopes to secure the co-operation of at least a small gendarmerie force, which would, with his own sowars, provide a backbone for the local troops that he will have to recruit for the purpose. The Serdar does not, however, propose to trust to the sword alone, but has already despatched a peace emissary in the person of Misbah-i-Diwan, a former Governor of Bunder Abbas, to treat with the Baluch leaders, with a view to reaching, if possible, a compromise that will enable an administration to be established without fighting. It is, however, I think, a good sign that an effort should be made to come to a friendly settlement of a question that is fraught with many difficulties. I HAVE the honour to bring forw r ard for consideration the question of the raiding by Baluchis into Kerman territory, and of the administration of the province of Persian Baluchistan. 2. It is unnecessary for me to deal with the origin of the existing situation. The course of events in recent years may be traced in Major Sykes’s w r ork “ Ten Thousand Miles through Persia,” and in the despatches and diaries of various consuls, concluding with those of my immediate predecessor, Lieutenant-Colonel Haig, C.M.G. 3. The total absence of any semblance of government in Baluchistan and the constant raids by its tribes into the neighbouring districts of Bam and Narmashir, not to mention forays further afield towards Khurasan, are sufficiently familiar. Also they do not ordinarily jeopardise to any serious extent British interests. In the present year, however, Baluchi activities have become less innocent from the British point of view. The district of Khabis, only three stages from Kerman city, was raided on more than one occasion, and Rawar, a weaving centre in which much foreign capital is engaged, was actually attacked. The raiders were beaten off with some loss of life on both sides, but a little more determination on the part of the Baluchis would have carried the day and a loss of thousands and thousands of pounds would have resulted to British subjects and proteges. 4. Not less serious in its potentialities, and very serious in its actual results, was the big Baluchi raid in May last into the country between Kerman and Bam. The districts of Tahrud, Darzin, and Marghak were stripped, and a large caravan on its wa y up from Bunder Abbas, with goods principally belonging to British Indian subjects, was gutted. The loss to us in this one episode was some 15,700 tomans odd, and it was only by a dispensation of Providence, or some similar force, that a caravan bringing specie for the Imperial Bank of Persia and accompanied by British subjects did not fall into their hands. 5. On this occasion, moreover, in the absence of the Governor-General with all available forces in Aqta Afshar, there was absolutely nothing to prevent the raiders coming straight on and pillaging Kerman city. It appears certain that they were not less than 600 in number, and it was probably only because they were glutted and lacked heart that they stayed their course and returned to their country. Since then we have had the raids into Khabis and Rawar already referred to, and a succession of forays into Narmashir and the vicinity of Bam. At the present time Bam and the villages of Narmashir are being daily menaced with devastation. 6. Such have been the circumstances of the year, and the question naturally follows: What steps have been taken to obtain reparation and to abate the Bahich nuisance ? The answer is: Almost nothing. As regards recoveries, nothing can be done without a punitive expedition, but an expedition was, in my opinion, not a thing to be undertaken with existing resources or under the auspices of a man like the Amir Mufakhkkam, who would only design and carry out such an undertaking in a way that would transfer the maximum of Government funds and of Baluch rv u Ho (No. 29. Confidential.)property into his own pockets without producing any permanent amelioration of the situation. I therefore abstained from pressing the authorities for the recovery of compen sation for the goods carried off at Marghak and Sarvistan, and even declined to interest ^nyself in trying to bring about a Baluchistan expedition for which the Amir Mufakh- kham was very insistent. His tour round the home districts had been a political necessity in order to re-establish the prestige of the Government in the parts of the country crossed by our trade routes, and on which the prosperity of Kerman is immediately dependent, but the same immediate necessity did not exist in the case of Baluchistan. 7. Nevertheless, the settlement of the Baluchi question is necessary, and it should he made of a permanent nature. The Baluch have been trying their strength, notably during the present year, and that they have the strength not only to sack Bam as well as the surrounding^districts, but also to make the western and hitherto safer route to Bunder Abbas via Deh Bakri impossible, and to loot Rawar, and even Kerman itself, during the absence of a Governor with a strong following like that of the Amir Mufakhkham, is beyond question. The only thing lacking so far is initiative and audacity. 8. It will be argued that the gendarmerie will be able to protect the Deh Bakri or any other route selected, and to guarantee the safety of Kerman city. This may be so in the course of time, but it is certainly beyond their power at present. To guarantee the safety of the road from Kerman to Deh Bakri, some 120 miles, on which the Baluch can at any time bring their full strength to bear, will require a large force. Prestige, when acquired, will reduce the force necessary, but the gendarmes have still their name to make, and any set-back or disaster will have a most damaging effect. The maintenance of a large force specially to counter the Baluch menace will in the long run be uneconomical. As regards Kerman, the presence of more than a gendarmerie depot in the city itself would be wasteful and inexpedient 9. It therefore seems to me that the Baluch evil should be attacked more directly and nearer the root. One step to this end would be the location of a cordon of Persian troops on the east frontier of Bam, and perhaps of Narmashir. As a move in this direction, I recommended earlier in the year that financial provision be made for the maintenance of a small mounted force by the Governor of Bam {vide my telegram No. 39/127, dated the 19th July, 1913). This was done, but it was only a trifling measure, whose chief value lay in its possible moral effect. In any case defensive measures, taken only to avoid offensive ones, are usually found in the long run to be expensive and unsatisfactory. Witness our policy on the north western frontier of India during the lift} 7 years preceding the revision of methods introduced by Lord Curzon. 10. I am therefore of opinion that the Baluchistan problem should be tackled by measures of- offence. But measures of offence are, in themselves, worthless or prejudicial unless they are merely the precursors of permanent administrative ones. It is no use paying the Baluch in their own coin, by mustering with difficulty a sufficient Persian force under Persian leaders, raiding the country, emptying it of stock and cash, and then withdrawing. This is what the Amir Mufakhkham would have done had he been able. The result would have been an impoverishment of the people, with a corresponding increase of criminality, and a sense of wrong with a desire for revenge which would find a vent for itself in renewed raiding and reprisals. 11. If Baluchistan is to be entered, it should be entered not again to be vacated by the Persian Government. A sufficient force should be raised to penetrate the country and establish a Government. Sardar deferred answering, and alleges to me that he does not want to accept Russian decoration. He suggests that if he is approached again he should report that he cannot accept without permission of Persian Uovernment, adding later, if necessary, that permission has been refused. He asked for my approval or advice, I replied I had no objection to course proposed. It may be that whole story is only ruse to induce us to give him a decora tion which might be prophylactic against Bakhtiaris. I made no sign apprecia ting this possibility. Enclosure No. 3. Telegram R., No. 159, dated (and received) the 17th November 1913. From—His Majesty’s Consul, Kerman, To—His Britannic Majesty’s Minister, Tehran. (Repeated Resident, Bushire, No. 221.) Sardar Nusrat complains he can get no answer from Sardar Muhtasham to request for authority to appoint Governor for Rafsinjan. He rightly points out matter is urgent as security Yazd road is at stake, and Rafsinjan is also postal centre through w r hich all Kerman posts pass. Enclosure No. 4. Telegram R., No. 160, dated (and received) the 17th November 1913. From—His Majesty’s Consul, Kerman, To—His Britannic Majesty’s Minister, Tehran. (Repeated Resident, Bushire, No. 222.) I send Your Excellency following report merely for information and for what it may be worth. People of Kerman are saying Bakhtiaris are meditating a coup of some sort and intend to meet at Ispahan and arrange matters there. They have come to understanding with Sowlet-ul-Mulk (sic) and can count on co-operation of Kashgais. Nature of coup is not openly stated, but is understood to be restoration of Muhammad Ali Shah It is credibly said that people of Kerman and Ears w’ould be in favour of restoration. This design on the part of Bakhtiaris pre sumably involves overthrow of Finance Department and gendarmerie. This is said to account for tame way in which Bakhtiari took gendarme affair in Tehran, and for Amir Mufakham suddenly wilfully playing the fool here, and then leaving province quietly without doing any serious damage. Enclosure No. 5. Telegram R., No. 99, dated (and received) the 18th November 1913. From—His Britannic Majesty's Minister, Tehran, To—His Majesty’s Consul, Kerman. (Repeated Resident, Bushire, No. 39 1 ‘) Your telegram* No. 160. I can quite understand in provinces people do ^ , not know true state of things. ♦Rnrlncnrp Nn. A ante. ^3 Bakbtiaris are not meditating any coup either at Ispahan or elsewhere. Muhammad Ali is politically asJSXtinct as the dodo, and Sowlet will very likely be deposed from Ilkhaniship of Kashgais in spring as he appears to have lost his authority over the tribesmen. Amir Mufakham came away quietly : he is a wise man and knows that his best chance of getting his money is by keeping on good terms with me. Enclosure No. 6. Telegram R., No. 163, dated the 25 th (received 27th) November 1913. From—His Majesty’s Consul, Kerman, From—His Britannic Majesty’s Minister, Tehran. (Repated Resident, Bushire No. 225.) Your telegram No. 101. Yes, a few days ago Lecoffre issued fresh notice announcing the imposition of vehicle tax but mentioning no date. I wrote enquiring the date proposed for commencing collection, but I have received no answer from him. Enclosure No. 7. Telegram R., No. 164, dated the 27th (received 28th) November 1913. From—His Majesty’s Consul, Kerman, To—His Britannic Majesty’s Minister, Tehran. (Repeated Resident, Bushire, No 226.) Your telegram No. 301. I interviewed Lecoffre yesterday. He says he has never received orders from any source to suspend introduc- tion of animal tax. Until your above mentioned telegram to myself I had only heard from late Governor-General of a vague order of suspension. I aske Sardar Nusrat recently and he said he had no instructions. Lecoffre says yearly licenses are already being applied for and paid for by people without any sign of opposition in any quarter. He did not propose to introduce immediately collection at the gates from non-residents. In these circumstances, I would strongly deprecate any retrograde action. Enclosure No. 8. Telegram R., No. 165, dated the 27th (received 28th) November 1913. From—His Majesty’s Consul, Kerman, To—His Britannic Majesty’s Minister, Tehran. (Repeated^Resident, Bushire, No. 227.) Sardar Nusrat asks for financial provision for a mounted force of 200 men and ammunition. This seems to me necessary and in view of withdrawal of Amir Mufakham s 5 or 600 sowars, logical. I have discussed matter with Lecoffre and we agree that Government should sanction monthly expenditure of 2,500 tomans as a temporary measure and purchase some 5> 000 cartridges. physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file. The subject 348 (Kerman affairs) consists of two volumes IOR/L/PS/10/334-335, with part 1 in the first and part 2 in the second volume.

Foliation: the foliation sequence commences at the inside front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 140; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The volume comprises correspondence between: the India Office, the Foreign Office, the Foreign Secretary to the Government of India, the British Consul for Kerman, the British Minister at Tehran, and the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, regarding affairs in Kerman.The subjects are:the movements of Baluchi raiders in the Province;the operations of the Swedish gendarmerie against Baluchi;the departure of the new Governor General from Tehran;Misbah-i-Divan, created Governor of Baluchistan, on a mission to pacify Persian Baluchistan;finances.There are copies of letters in French, from Major G Glimstedt, Commanding the IV Regiment of the Gendarmerie Gouvernementale at Kerman.The volume comprises part 2 of two. Each part includes a divider which gives the subject and part numbers, year the subject file was opened, subject heading, and list of correspondence references contained in that part by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
